title.rendered: The Parable of the Wedding Feast PART 3 – By Phil the Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“But when the king came in to see the guests, he saw a man there﻿﻿who did not have on a wedding garment. ﻿12﻿ So he said to him, ‘Friend, how did you come in here without a wedding garment?’ And he was ﻿ ﻿speechless (Matt. 22:11-12)

There is a Kingdom vindication.  “But when the king heard about it, he was furious. And he sent out ﻿﻿his armies, destroyed those murderers, and burned up their city (Matt 22:7).  The King cares about his Kingdom servants, and he did not sit idly by while his servants were being persecuted for their duties in serving their king.  No, he would not stand for this when he heard the news.  His anger welled up within him and he became furious.  The most powerful one in this parable became angry and he would unleash his anger upon his enemies. He had invited many people to the banquet by the word of his servants, and previously some made light of it, and others were persecuted because of the message they carried from the king.  However, the king would vindicate his servants proclaiming that they would not die in vain.  He immediately dispatched his army, and destroyed the murders and burned up their city.  The people and the land were destroyed.  His servants had gone out with the invitation, but when persecuted, he sent his soldiers out with judgment to vindicate his servants.  Recall with me when Cain killed able.  God said to Cain, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood ﻿cries out to Me from the ground (Gen 4:10).  I can imagine that those persecuted to death by the king’s enemies I can picture that their blood as well cried out to their king a prayer as from the psalmist in Psalm 26. Vindicate ﻿﻿me, O Lord, For I have ﻿﻿walked in my integrity. ﻿﻿I have also trusted in the Lord; I shall not slip (26:1). Do ﻿not gather my soul with sinners, Nor my life with bloodthirsty men, In whose hands is a sinister scheme, And whose right hand is full of ﻿﻿bribes.

If you belong to the king and have been persecuted for your faith in Christ, or those you know belong to him have been persecuted to the death, do not believe for a second that the Lord has overlooked this.  He can hear even the blood that cries from the ground for his beloved servants, and he will make vindication for His names sake, so He will be glorified!  Do you thank Him for this? 

Kingdom Inspection will be made.  Notice who it was that came in to see the guests.  It was the king!  I can imagine that he was enjoying the sight of his guests each having a good time, each enjoying the company of one another, and the food that the kingdom so graciously provided for them to eat.  As the king scanned the room, he saw each person properly dressed for the wedding, but then suddenly he eyes came across one that “did not look like the others.”  As the King inspected each person he himself saw one man without the wedding garment.  The king did not and would not overlook this man.  He didn’t say, “Well it’s only one person out of the multitude of guests, so I will simply overlook this man’s attire.”  No, not at all!  The king summoned the man to himself and questioned him as to why he did not have on a wedding garment at a wedding, after this was the occasion.  God will be the one that will inspect each person’s life one day.  When he inspects your life, what will He find?  Will you have on the wedding garment?   

    
The Kingdom wedding garment MUST be worn! Many people were called to the banquet, but according to the king’s requirements. It is evident that wearing this wedding garment was a requirement for the banquet.  John MacArthur masterfully shares, “All without exception were invited to the banquet, so this man is not to be viewed as a common party-crasher. In fact, all the guests were rounded up hastily from “the highways” and therefore none could be expected to come with proper attire. That means the wedding garments were supplied by the king himself. So this man’s lack of a proper garment indicates he had purposely rejected the king’s own gracious provision. His affront to the king was actually a greater insult than those who refused to come at all, because he committed his impertinence in the very presence of the king. The imagery seems to represent those who identify with the kingdom externally, profess to be Christians, belong to the church in a visible sense—yet spurn the garment of righteousness Christ offers as Isaiah wrote, “﻿I will greatly rejoice in the Lord, My soul shall be joyful in my God;  For ﻿﻿He has clothed me with the garments of salvation, He has covered me with the robe of righteousness, ﻿﻿As a bridegroom decks himself with ornaments, And as a bride adorns herself with her jewel.

Instead they seek to establish a righteousness of their own (see Rom. 10:3; Phil. 3:8, 9). Ashamed to admit their own spiritual poverty, they refuse the better garment the King graciously offers—and thus they are guilty of a horrible sin against His goodness.”  Do you have the wedding garment on at this time?

To be continued…

Until the nets are filled… 
Blessings, Phil Sessa, Evangelist – Soulfishing Ministries

content.rendered: Good morning, Hope you had a great long weekend. On Friday I was out on the streets witnessing, talked to about 10 people directly and indirectly, gave out gospel tracts. Met some Christians too who I had a chance to challenge. Everyone was open to the gospel and were very glad I was out there to share with them the truth, but yesterday Monday was a different story, there was rejection after rejection, overwhelming and discouraging but here I receive a devotion that is encouraging from the Lord to strengthen us not to quit, I needed this. The enemy wants us to quit fighting, I will not quit reaching the lost, neither should you with whatever he is trying to use to make you quit. Ev Good morning, Acts 18:9 “One night the Lord spoke to Paul in a vision: “Do not be afraid; keep on speaking, do not be silent.10 For I am with you, and no one is going to attack and harm you, because I have many people in this city.” God spoke Encouraging Words to Paul! God did not want Paul to quit and he wants none of you to quit as well. Got that? “A man was shoveling snow from his driveway when two boys carrying snow shovels approached him. “Can we shovel your snow mister?” one of them asked. “Only two dollars!” Puzzled the man replied, “Can’t you see that I’m doing it myself.” “Sure,” said one of the enterprising young men, “that’s why we asked. We get most of our business from people who are half through and feel like quitting.” While working for a multinational company, I would struggle and writhe in pain when I look at the atrocities around, foul language, immodest dressing and crazy living, I would wonder, “how am I going to present the Gospel to them”. I would just walk to a person while at the coffee machine and say, “can I get a moment please”, then I would rattle off my testimony. All the while I would see the other person’s eyes wonder around, though my heart would pound when I look at the person’s uneasiness, yet I would end my testimony quoting the Bible. I would walk around during lunch and tea time with the Bible in my hand. People looked strangely at me and until the last working day in the bank, many people avoided me. Friend, if you want to really walk close with Jesus, then the world would leave you. God trained me to be ALONE and now I am reaping the fruits of my labor for Christ. The Lord is teaching me many things which I would not have learnt if I had not separated myself for Him. Many people rejected me and asked me not to disturb them anymore. While distributing tracts on the roads and highways, I would sometimes be stared at and just ignored. Though it pains to be rejected but now I know I was on a mission for Christ. I would just pass on to the next person. Many times, God would whisper a word of encouragement and I would happily continue. In the above scripture, not only is Paul overwhelmed with the immorality of Corinth; he is very much alone. Paul had left all of his co-workers, Silas and Timothy behind. But we see that many people were set on fire for God because of Paul. Even in a city like Corinth, God had some people who had the thirst to work for God but it needs FIRE to light it. You never know, there may be some Aquilla, Priscilla, Crispus and Apollos among you in the office. It needs a person like Paul to go around and HUNT for them for Christ. Will you be THAT PAUL? http://www.worshipjesusministry.com by Sis. Bala Samson

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 84:1-12, “For a day in Your courts is better than a thousand. I would rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God Than dwell in the tents of wickedness”

Psalm 84 is a beautiful psalm I love, I love the way NIV begins in verse 1, “How lovely is Your dwelling place, O LORD Almighty!.” How did he know that God’s dwelling place was lovely? I believe that as he began to worship and praise the Lord in His house, he found himself in a new place. He went past the gates of praise into the sanctuary (inner courts) to seek His face. If God is beautiful and lovely, His dwelling place is beautiful and lovely. Can you imagine what heaven is like? Anything we experience down here before the Lord is just a taste of what heaven is like.

Psalm 84:2, “My soul longs, yes, even faints For the courts of the LORD; My heart and my flesh cry out for the living God”. Are we longing for the presence of the Almighty God? Some even rising up to be in the house of God is a drag but I heard David say Psalm 122:1, “I was glad when they said to me, “Let us go into the house of the LORD.” He couldn’t wait to be there. It wasn’t about what he could gain in the house but what he could give. He so much longs for the presence of God such that his heart and flesh cry out to God. Though my heart is anxious to know the Lord, the flesh constantly fights the heart. When you know you are not where you need to be, something within you will long for something greater than what you already have inside. Something that will propel you to leave the visible and long for the invisible. Something that will cause you to see things not in the natural but in the supernatural. It’s easy to get satisfied by what you see naturally, but when God brings you to a place like where the psalmist found himself, your spirit will yearn for more. His secret, he sought for it, this goes so much with Mathew 6:33, “Seek ye first the kingdom of God“. Psalm 84 vs.  4&5, “Blessed are those who dwell in Your house; They will still be praising You. 5, Blessed is the man whose strength is in You,..”. You can desire a blessing but first things first. Have you thrown church out of the window, instead of being in the house of the Lord to bless His name on a Sunday morning, you’d rather do something else than desire His blessing for the week? His house is not reserved for certain occasions.

In His house that is where there is refuge and safety, that is where He speaks to you through His chosen servants, the train of His robe fills the temple (His house). It’s the best place to be at and meet Him. The psalmist discovered and realized that just a day in his dwelling place, is better than a thousand days elsewhere. Even if it meant not being in a position to be in His house, he would still be comfortable at the entrance. God cares for His house and He cares for His people to be in His house to worship and praise Him, to meet Him in the inner courts. Do you get excited about being in his house or is it just another drag? When was the last time you were in His house? Get your life back on  track. Find a church that reads and preaches the bible, a church that prays, and worships the Lord God Almighty, and be plugged in His house.  Blessings Ev

title.rendered: The Parable of the Wedding Feast PART 2 – By Phil the Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning, 
12 So he said to him, ‘Friend, how did you come in here without a wedding garment?’ And he was speechless. (Matt 22:12) 
In part 1 of the Parable of the Wedding Feast, we looked at the reality of the Kingdom of God, and how it is opposed to the Kingdom of this world.  Jesus has a Kingdom, and the Kingdom of God dwells within His children.  The Kingdom of this world should not the one that God’s people chase after, but rather they should embrace the Kingdom of God, and the King (God) of the Kingdom! 

There is a Kingdom banquet!  However, not only does a heavenly Kingdom exist, but there is a Kingdom banquet!  The king threw a banquet on behalf of his son’s marriage.  Tell those who are invited, “See, I have prepared my dinner; ﻿﻿my oxen and fatted cattle are killed, and all things are ready. Come to the wedding.  The king made that everything was prepared to his liking and his will.  He ordered the meal, and wanted to make sure everything was set just right.  The King is still throwing a banquet.  John wrote in the book of Revelation, “﻿9﻿Then he said to me, “Write: ﻿‘Blessed are those who are called to the marriage supper of the Lamb (19:9)!’  There is still a GREAT DAY coming for those that are the Bride of Christ, which will partake in wedding feast in Heaven.  Will you be there?  When Jesus sent out the 70 on their ministry assignment, they came back rejoicing that darkness (the demons) were subject to their authority in Christ.  However Christ said, “Nevertheless do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you, but [omit] rather rejoice because ﻿﻿your names are written [engraved] in heaven (Luke 10:20).”  You may have your name written on your birth certificate, on your social security card, on your marriage license, and one day your name will be written on a tomb stone. But if your name is not written in the Lambs (Phil 4:3; Rev. 3:5), it does not matter if your name is written anywhere else.  Those that have their names written in heaven’s role, will be the ONLY ones that will be at the Marriage Supper of the Lamb.   

The Kingdom servants spread the news!  “and sent out his servants to call those who were invited to the wedding; and they were not willing to come. ﻿4﻿Again, he sent out other servants, saying, ‘Tell those who are invited, “See, I have prepared my dinner; ﻿my oxen and fatted cattle are killed, and all things are ready. Come to the wedding.”  The King sent the servants out, and they obediently went out as the King commanded.  They were to call all those invited to the wedding, but those they called were not willing to come.  Still the king sent more servants out to tell those invited that the king has prepared a banquet table and his killed both his oxen killed and the fatted calf for the celebration.  God is still sending his servants out to call people the upcoming banquet.  Jesus sent His disciples out to minister (Luke 10) and his last words “Go into all the world ﻿﻿and preach the gospel to every creature.”  Instead of staying in all the church building, Jesus said “Go into all the world…”  We are to be mobile, and that involves MOVEMENT.  As you are going into all the world (the place you live, your community, the people you know, and the strangers you meet) you are to preach the Gospel.  ﻿20﻿ Now then, we are ﻿ambassadors for Christ, as though God were pleading through us: we implore you on Christ’s behalf, be reconciled to God (2 Cor. 5:20).”  The Gospel is simply the good news that Christ Jesus alone has paid the penalty (fine) for the Law (the 10 Commandments) that you and I have broken.  “While we were yet sinners Christ died for us.” So to partake in this you are commanded to “Repent therefore and be converted, that your sins may be blotted out, so that times of refreshing may come from the presence of the Lord (Acts 3:19).”  Why is this crucial?  “And as it is appointed for men to die once, ﻿but after this the judgment (Heb 9:27).”  A servant obeys his or her master.  Jesus said, “But why do you call Me ‘Lord, Lord,’ and not do the things which I say?  This is why Paul’ heart was so burdened that he proclaimed, “For Christ did not send me to baptize, but to preach the gospel (1 Cor. 1:17).”  “For if I preach the gospel, I have nothing to boast of, for ﻿necessity is laid upon me; yes, woe is me if I do not preach the gospel! ﻿17﻿ For if I do this willingly, ﻿﻿I have a reward; but if against my will, ﻿I have been entrusted with a stewardship. ﻿18﻿ What is my reward then? That ﻿when I preach the gospel, I may present the gospel ﻿of Christ without charge, that I ﻿may not abuse my authority in the gospel (1 Cor 9:16-18).”

Kingdom servants will be persecuted.  “But they made light of it and went their ways, one to his own farm, another to his business. ﻿6﻿And the rest seized his servants, treated them ﻿﻿spitefully, and killed them.”  Some will outright reject the call and make light of it.  I spoke to someone just recently, and he said, “I’m just not into that,” when I shared the Gospel with him, making light of his need for a Savior.  Those that are servants of the King (God) are godly people, and God has promised something for them to look forward to.  Paul wrote, “Yes, and ﻿﻿all who desire to live godly in Christ Jesus will suffer persecution (2 Tim 3:12).  The king in the parable sent out his servants, and his servants were seized, spitefully treated, and even killed.  But there is another promise from God here, straight from the lips of Jesus.  Jesus said, “﻿﻿Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, For theirs is the kingdom of heaven.  11﻿﻿﻿“Blessed are you when they revile and persecute you, and say all kinds of ﻿﻿evil against you falsely for My sake. ﻿12﻿ ﻿﻿Rejoice and be exceedingly glad, for great is your reward in heaven, for ﻿﻿so they persecuted the prophets who were before you (Matt 5:10-12).”  This is not the kind of promises that most focus on, but in the full council of God, one cannot leave out these types promises in 2 Tim 3:12; Matt. 5:10-12.  The servants of the king were blessed by the persecution that they received as they received it on behalf of their king.       To be continued…

Until the nets are filled… 
Blessings, Phil Sessa, Evangelist – Soulfishing Ministries <><

title.rendered: The Parable of the Wedding Feast PART 1 – By Phil the Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning,

12﻿ So he said to him, ‘Friend, how did you come in here without a wedding garment?’ And he was ﻿﻿speechless. (Matt 22:12)

I can imagine at celebrity weddings, that each person allowed to attend the event must be on a guest list at the front entrance.  You see not just anyone can walk into an event with a bunch of celebrities and be allowed in.  Some will certainly try to manipulate their way in claiming they should be on the list, and perhaps even name someone else they are acquainted with which is on the list, however the one checking the names at the front entrance will not let the person in because they have no right to be there.  Jesus told a similar account in Matt 22.

And Jesus answered ﻿﻿and spoke to them again by parables and said: ﻿2﻿“The kingdom of heaven is like a certain king who arranged a marriage for his son, ﻿3﻿ and sent out his servants to call those who were invited to the wedding; and they were not willing to come. ﻿4﻿Again, he sent out other servants, saying, ‘Tell those who are invited, “See, I have prepared my dinner; ﻿my oxen and fatted cattle are killed, and all things are ready. Come to the wedding.” ’ ﻿5﻿ But they made light of it and went their ways, one to his own farm, another to his business. ﻿6﻿ And the rest seized his servants, treated them ﻿﻿spitefully, and killed them. ﻿7﻿ But when the king heard about it, he was furious. And he sent out ﻿his armies, destroyed those murderers, and burned up their city. ﻿8﻿ Then he said to his servants, ‘The wedding is ready, but those who were invited were not﻿﻿worthy. ﻿9﻿ Therefore go into the highways, and as many as you find, invite to the wedding.’ ﻿10﻿ So those servants went out into the highways and gathered together all whom they found, both bad and good. And the wedding hall was filled with guests.

The Kingdom of God EXISTS!  “The kingdom of heaven is like a certain king who arranged a marriage for his son.” In Matthew’s Gospel, he wrote on Jesus’ repetitive statement “The Kingdom of Heaven is like…,”which appears about ten times in his writing.    Jesus is using this parable to describe the Kingdom of God, which is a kingdom many in this world don’t contemplate much about.  Someone is either a part of the Kingdom of God or the Kingdom of this world.  The kingdom of this world may tantalize many, with its music, entertainment, glamour, etc…, yet we are to resist these things, because they are NOTHING compared to the Kingdom of our God.  In Matthew 4, and Luke 4, Jesus is tempted by Satan himself, and one of Satan’s temptations to lure Jesus in was to show and promise Jesus to own the kingdoms of the world.  Matthew wrote, “﻿8﻿ Again, the devil took Him up on an exceedingly high mountain, and ﻿﻿showed Him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. ﻿9﻿ And he said to Him, “All these things I will give You if You will fall down and worship me.”  The Devil seemed to believe that Jesus would jump at this gift the Devil was offering Him.  The kingdoms of this world are the Devil’s to give, as “﻿the god of this age (world) ﻿has blinded, who do not believe, lest ﻿﻿the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, ﻿who is the image of God, should shine on them.”   Yet Jesus would not give in to this.  What are the kingdoms of this world compared to the Kingdom of Heaven anyhow?  The term Kingdom means “rule,” “reign” or “authority” (not a king’s people or land, as connotations of the English term could imply). Jewish people recognized that God rules the universe now, but they prayed for the day when he would rule the world unchallenged by idolatry and disobedience. The coming of this future aspect of God’s reign was generally associated with the Messiah and the resurrection of the dead. Because Jesus came and will come again, Christians believe that the kingdom has been inaugurated but awaits consummation or completion. “Kingdom of heaven” is another way (Matthew’s usual way) of saying “kingdom of God.” “Heaven” was a standard Jewish way of saying “God” (as in Lk 15:21) (Bible Backgrounds Commentary).

Jesus had (and still has) a Heavenly eternal kingdom and would not “trade it” for a temporary earthly one.  He was the Gospel that was shining brighter and greater than ANY kingdom the Devil could allure Him with.  So what did Jesus do at this point?  Did he pray, yell, scream, or “cast Satan out”?  No!  Jesus used the Word of God, the Scriptures to combat his enemy.  He did say say “Get behind me Satan (Luke 4) and “Away from me Satan (Matt 4) but it was coupled with the Word of God.  I heard of a false teacher that claimed t to be a Christian Pastor say, “The Bible is not the Word of God, it is words about God.”  The Bible makes it clear over and over, that the Bible is the written Word of God, which is why Jesus used the phrase over and over “It is written…” Here is the were Jesus displayed this truth in his final combat with Satan on the mount of temptation.  “Then Jesus said to him, ﻿﻿“Away with you, Satan! For it is written, ‘You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him only you shall serve.’ ”Jesus used the Word of the King Himself!  This is the same power that drove the demons out of demonized people when they encountered the Christ.  The King Word’s is sure.  “For ever, O Lord Your Word is settled in heaven (Psalm 119:89)   What was the result of Jesus using the Word of the King?  ﻿11﻿ “Then the devil ﻿﻿left Him, and behold, ﻿﻿angels came and ministered to Him.”

  1. The King here represents God Himself, so serve the king faithfully!  To be continued…  

Until the nets are filled… 
Blessings Phil Sessa, Evangelist Soulfishing Ministries

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 3:1-21, “The Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them”

We looked at God the Creator stepping in making Adam and Eve garments and not only making them garments, but He also clothed them. We also saw how the plans of God are executed in heaven to be performed and perfected here on earth. We pray let Your will be done here on earth as it is done in heaven in other words, let your architectural plan for our lives be performed and perfected here on earth.

When the prodigal son went to a far country and squandered everything, he came back home desiring to be made a slave but the father had a different plan for his son Luke 15:20-22, 21 And the son said unto him, Father, I have sinned against heaven, and in thy sight, and am no more worthy to be called thy son. 22 But the father said to his servants, Bring forth the best robe, and put it on him;…”. The one that deserved to be punished received the best robe (garment), a chance to become what he missed. His father’s love, his attitude of humility and repentance opened a door for restoration. In Isaiah 61:3, “And provide for those who grieve in Zion-to bestow on them a crown of beauty, instead of ashes, the oil of gladness instead of mourning, and garment of praise instead of spirit of despair” (NIV). Amen, the Lord already has a covering for those who are mourning and again we see that the plan He structured in heaven, He is commanding His chosen ones to execute them here on earth by telling them to provide unto the grieving in Zion a crown of beauty, oil of gladness and the garments of praise. Many are struggling to worship because they are wearing garments of heaviness leading to depression, confusion, brokenness, have no joy, but the Lord would have His word come to you who is struggling today, “I have a garment of praise for the spirit of despair to give to you, I will take what you have and replace it with what I have, garments of praise”.

Joseph in the book of Genesis had a father who loved him so much so he made him something special, Genesis 37:3, “Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his children, because he was the son of his old age. Also he made him a tunic (coat, robe) of many colors“. Jacob had a reason for making his son a coat of many colors. I see it this way, though Joseph had a coat of many colors, he did not know that was symbolic for when he was sold into Egypt and later became the number 2 man, he was able to serve everyone without discrimination, he was able to serve all races, colors, personalities, and  gender in other words, he served everyone equally. We’ve received Jesus, the coat of many colors, we can now serve anyone and every one for what we were not we are now because of Him

Time fails me for there are so much about the garments we could learn from for example, Jesus wore garments while here on earth and we see a woman with the issue of blood reaching out to touch the hem His garments in Mathew 9:20 and when he had been crucified, the soldiers parted His garments among them. There is something about the garments and we are blessed to have God prepare and clothe us with them.

I’m glad He’s got me covered, my needs, desires, dreams, ambitions, and goals are covered. When you think that nothing is happening, just remember that He’s got you covered, you may not feel it but it’s not a matter of feeling, it’s a matter of knowing and believing that He has His garments on you. Prayer covers us; and just like the paint covers the surface when applied, the blood of Jesus has covered us. “The Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them”, NOT ONLY DOES HE MAKE THE GARMENTS FOR US, HE’S GOT US COVERED WITH THEM. Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 3:1-21, “The Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them”

A garment is a type of coat or robe especially used for official purposes. In Genesis after the fall of man, Adam and Eve having had knowledge they were naked decided to cover themselves by making  clothing out of leaves. When men fell; 1. Immediately knew they had failed God, 2. Discovered they were naked and 3. Developed a need to hide. We understand that there are things as human beings we can do on our own and might work but the truth is, it will not last for long. They had leaves covering them not realizing that leaves would soon dry up and fall.  So man tries so hard to cover his nakedness only for it to work but for a season. The bible tells me that there are things that if God does not do, anything someone else will do will be in vain. Psalm 127:1, “Except the Lord builds the house, they labor in vain that build it: Except the Lord keep the city, the watchman waketh in vain”. I would say that this verse means that anything you are going to do if the Lord is not involved in it, however hard you try and do it, it will never work.

Genesis 3:21, “The Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them”. Here comes the Lord who knows that whatever man will do, will not work unless He steps in. He made garments of skin for Adam and his wife. Lets pause here for a sec, the Lord did not tell them what to do and how to do it, He stepped in and did it for them. We see the first death of an animal, the first sacrifice. Even in the midst of their failure, God still knew how vulnerable man was without Him therefore He reached out to the poor material “man” and does something for him. Remember the scripture we just looked at, “Except or unless the Lord does it, man will be doing it in vain”. Whatever the Lord does comes already blessed, he can only bless what His hands are on. I also wondered why garments and nothing else, let’s look at why the Lord loves garments, In Exodus 28:1-5, God is giving instructions to Moses on what to do about the priests He had appointed (Aaron and his sons). Look at Exodus 28:2, “Make sacred garments for your brother Aaron, to give himdignity and honor, vs. 3, “Tell all the skilled men to whom I have given wisdom in such matters that they are to make garments for Aaron, for his consecration, so he may serve me as a priest”.Can you see that the garments were to give him dignity and honor and then for his consecration. In the olden times, the priests ministered to the Lord and brought messages from the Lord to the people. There were people who were given special tasks to do this kind of service, when Jesus died on the cross, the ones who received Him, He gave them power to become, and now we are priests who minister to the Lord daily. Only God could clothe us again with dignity and honor by sending His Son to the cross to die for the shamed human race and He says in Romans 13:14, “Put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ … “,putting on the Lord Jesus gives us dignity and honor and we get consecrated which is to say being set apart for the Master. God had to clothe us with Jesus to remove all our guilt and shame. NOT ONLY DID HE PROVIDE THE GARMENTS, HE ALSO CLOTHED THEM.

The garments were not made of cheap imitated materials, lets go back to Exodus 28:4, “These are garments they are to make: a breast piece, an ephod, a robe, a woven tunic, a turban and a sash vs. 5, “have them use gold, and blue, and purple and scarlet yarn, and the fine linen“. We said God is skillful in making things, everything is done systematically and goes through different stages. Because this was a special project ordained by Him, the skilled men could not make the garments outside His instructions (Except the Lord builds the house, they labor in vain), it’s like God is giving them the architectural plan executed in heaven in readiness for the building down here. The plan, the structure, what kind of materials to be used, budgeted for in heaven and by God. Him giving the final architectural plan is a sign that He has built it already. Yes it may still look like it’s ink and paper but it’s a done job. He calls those things which are not as though they were. Our garments are skillfully designed in heaven and God is executing that plan here on earth through His Son and the Holy Spirit. Garments reserved for us are not made of cheap materials and they are not just made, they are skillfully designed by the Creator of all. It’s a blessing to know that my garments is CUSTOMIZED  and has the label “JESUS”, He is the reason for the garment. Let’s look at different garments in the morning. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Keep the Lamp Burning, part 3 (by Phil Sessa)

content.rendered:
Good morning, 
Thirdly, the Lampstands were to SHINE CONTINUOUSLY.  
Our light is never to have a blackout, because we have a power source that is from heaven in the Holy Spirit of whose power can never fail.  Why is the power flowing through our lives?  Luke states in Acts 1:8, “But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth.”  The Greek word for witness is “martyr.”  In other words, the power of the Holy Spirit is the power to live for Him and die for Him if necessary.  We might not all physically be persecuted to the point of death, but should be willing to because we so love our Lord.  The writer of Hebrews wrote, “Others suffered mocking and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment. 37They were stoned, they were sawn in two,﻿ ﻿they were killed with the sword. They went about in skins of sheep and goats, destitute, afflicted, mistreated— 38of whom the world was not worthy.”  The world is truly not worthy of those that go through such things for the honor of Jesus, but Christ IS worthy of them!  Would you be counted as one of them of whom the world is not worthy?  In re-examining this abridged list, what was it about these dear saints that caused others to attempt to and even succeed in many cases to take their very lives, unto death.  These dear ones keep their commitment to Christ, similar to, but spiritually speaking, a marriage vow between a husband and wife.  I recall the words at my marriage with my dear wife and saying the words, “till death do us part.”  Those were a word of intense commitment to the very best friend God has given me in my wife.  However the difference is, she can’t give me the power to keep my vow, neither can I give her the power to keep hers, but God can and does day to day.  How much more, as the bride of Christ, should we live out the commitment, “till death do we part?”  However, with Christ, He gives me the power to stay committed to Him, even when I fall at times, and fail.  And with Christ it really not do us part, because those that are His will be with Him and “see Him as He is.”  The hymn writer penned the famous words of, What a Day That Will Be:

What a day that will be

When my Je-sus I shall see,

And I look up-on His face,

The one who saved me by His grace.

When He takes me by the hand,

And leads me through the Prom-ised Land,

What a day, glo-ri-ous day that will be.

  
The men written about and martyred for Christ in the book of Hebrews lived and preached the unadulterated Gospel of Jesus Christ and they paid dearly for it with their very lives.  Shining the light, is living for and preaching the Gospel that Jesus preached.  This is not a popular message, it is not a politically correct message, it is not a message the world wants to hear even though it is the one they need to hear.  Yet it is the message that He has commanded His “Lampstand Children” to keep burning and so much so that this light will shine forth from our lives.  Jesus said of Himself, ““I am the light of the world. He who follows Me shall not walk in darkness, but have the light of life (John 9:5).” If you are following Him you cannot at the same time walk in darkness.  Furthermore, he states in Matt. 5, ﻿﻿“You are the light of the world. A city that is set on a hill cannot be hidden. ﻿15﻿ Nor do they ﻿﻿light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a lampstand, and it gives light to all who are in the house.﻿ 16﻿Let your light so shine before men, ﻿﻿that they may see your good works and ﻿﻿glorify your Father in heaven (14 – 16).”  So you might be wondering is who is the light?  Is Jesus the light of the world or are His children the light of the world?  The answer is yes.  Both Christ and His children are the light of the world, because His light should obviously be shining forth from His children!  Matthew points out that this light is like a city set on a hill which cannot be hidden, but rather put on a LAMPSTAND to give light to ALL that are in the house.  “An elevated city at night would have torch lights that would make it visible to the surrounding countryside. The small wicker oil lamps of this period gave little light in the average home, which had few windows; they would be most effective by being set on a lampstand. Something large placed over them would presumably extinguish the light altogether (IVP Bible Backgrounds NT).”  What can be placed over a child of Christ that can hold back and extinguish the light of Christ from shining forth from His vessel?  Luke wrote concerning the emanating light, “The lamp of the body is the eye. Therefore, when your eye is good, your whole body also is full of light. But when your eye is bad (evil, unhealthy), your body also is full of darkness. ﻿35﻿Therefore take heed that the light which is in you is not darkness. ﻿36﻿ If then your whole body is full of light, having no part dark, the whole body will be full of light, as when the bright shining of a lamp gives you light (Luke 11:33-36).”

Jeremiah seemingly tried to put a clamp on it, and cover up the light and fire, saying “I will not make mention of Him, nor speak any more in his name. But his word was in mine heart as a burning fire shut up in my bones, and I was weary with forbearing, and I could not stay.”  He couldn’t keep it contained, and if have the everlasting Gospel in you, the Spirit of God in you, then you too will not be able to contain it, and it will shine forth from you, that burning fire in your lamp stand life will come out, it has to.  If it doesn’t then I think it is safe to say, it is because Christ is not in you.  Toothpaste comes out of a toothpaste tube, and Christ’s light will come out of Christians!  Is your light shining before a world living in darkness?  If you are shining continuously then you will have an effect upon the world of darkness, this same world (before you repented) that you were in love with.  God spoke light into darkness in Genesis, and desires His light to shine through you!  John writes, 18﻿ ﻿﻿“He who believes in Him is not condemned; but he who does not believe is condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. ﻿19﻿ And this is the condemnation, ﻿that the light has come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil. ﻿20﻿ For ﻿ ﻿everyone practicing evil hates the light and does not come to the light, lest his deeds should be exposed. ﻿21﻿ But he who does the truth comes to the light, that his deeds may be clearly seen, that they have been ﻿﻿done in God.”

Remember you are the gold vessel display of God reflecting His image to the world, as His ambassador.  Recognize that God hammers those that He uses to display His handiwork and His glory in the earth.  Recall that you are to shine continuously in a world of darkness never hiding your light. 

Until the nets are filled… 
Blessings, Phil the Evangelist <><

title.rendered: Keep the Lamp Burning, Part 2 by Phil Sessa

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: ﻿2﻿ ﻿﻿“Command the children of Israel that they bring to you pure oil of pressed olives for the light, to make the lamps burn continually. ﻿3﻿ Outside the veil of the Testimony, in the tabernacle of meeting, Aaron shall be in charge of it from evening until morning before the Lord continually; it shall be a statute forever in your generations. ﻿4﻿ He shall ﻿be in charge of the lamps on ﻿﻿the pure gold lampstand before the Lord continually (Lev. 24:1-4).

Secondly, The lampstand shall be of hammered work.

The way the Lampstand is shaped is crucial.  The psalmist wrote, “Unless the Lord builds the house, they labor in vain who build it (Psalm 127:1).”  The proper building and structure of things was very important to God.  Without the proper dimensions, would Noah’s Ark have floated?  The tabernacle has specific dimensions, and specific materials were to be used for everything.  The Lampstand needed to be of a hammered work.  Hammering involves banging, striking repeatedly until the object is fit into place.  It would seem that when God has a way of hammering His people when needed to display His power and glory.  If God is going to use a person mightily for His name sake, honor and glory, the vessel must be one of humility.  Moses, spent 40 years in Egypt thinking he was somebody great, followed by 40 years in the Midian Desert thinking he was no body special.  Then at age 80, God called Moses and showed Moses what God could do with somebody who thinks them self to be nobody, and then realizes that God, not Himself, is truly GREAT!  God must humble us before He can use us.  God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble.  We must be humble hearted to be mightily used by God, because one can only minister obediently and effectively by HIS GRACE!  If one ministers in their name, their own power, and their own way, God is not glorified through the life of that vessel as far as that vessel submitting to God so that He would specifically be glorified through that ministry.  I recall many times when I have been hammered by God, because of my own pride of heart, and my own selfish desires.  God allows trials, and even persecution to come our way to hammer into the vessels He is pleased with. 

The writer of Hebrews 12 put forth, “﻿3﻿ ﻿For consider Him who endured such hostility from sinners against Himself, ﻿ ﻿lest you become weary and discouraged in your souls. ﻿4﻿ ﻿You have not yet resisted to bloodshed, striving against sin. ﻿5﻿ And you have forgotten the exhortation which speaks to you as to sons:

“My son, do not despise the ﻿chastening of the Lord, Nor be discouraged when you are rebuked by Him;6   For ﻿whom the Lord loves He chastens,And scourges every son whom He receives.”

title.rendered: Keep the Lamp Burning, Part 1 by Pastor Phil Sessa

content.rendered:
Good morning

Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: ﻿2﻿ ﻿﻿“Command the children of Israel that they bring to you pure oil of pressed olives for the light, to make the lamps burn continually. ﻿3﻿ Outside the veil of the Testimony, in the tabernacle of meeting, Aaron shall be in charge of it from evening until morning before the Lord continually; it shall be a statute forever in your generations. ﻿4﻿ He shall ﻿be in charge of the lamps on ﻿﻿the pure goldlampstand before the Lord continually (Lev. 24:1-4).

I recall the blackout in NYC that took place years ago.  Many people were left without power because something went haywire in the power grid.  So many that relied on that grid for their electricity, had no power.  Others turned to battery power, and or generators.  In the book of Exodus, the plans for the Tabernacle were laid out.  In verses 31–40, the plans, and care for the Gold Lampstand was given.  In the above verses in Leviticus further instructions were given for the care of these Lampstands.  I believe that many of the physical realities of the Old Testament become New Testament spiritual realities.

First, the Lampstands were made of Gold.  
The New Testament verses that come to mind are the following:  “For we are ﻿His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand that we should walk in them (Eph 2:10).  God has made us His workmanship.  The Greek word for workmanship ispoiema whereby we derive the word poem.  We are God’s poem that He has created, because Christ through the Holy Spirit is in our very lives!  We obviously are created (physically) but we are created in Christ Jesus (spiritually) when we were born again by His Spirit.  We are created IN CHRIST Jesus, for a purpose, and he describes that purpose.   God has created in…for good works.  God actually prepared what good works for us beforehand, so this way we would not focus on “works” that we desire, but rather submit to serve God in the works that he has prescribed for us to carry out.  A servant is one that does the will of his master.   Paul wrote in 2 Corinthians 4:7, “But we have this treasure in jars of clay, ﻿to show that the surpassing power belongs to God and not to us.” God sees our jars of clay as gold to which he can shine forth from.  The Gospel is truly a treasure, and it is in our lives to show that surpassing power belongs to God and not to us.  God deserves to ALWAYS get the glory.  We are certainly to shine our light, the light of Christ shining forth from our lives, as Matthew 5:16 reads, “In the same way, let your light shine before others, so that they may see your good works and give glory to your Father who is in heaven.”  God gets that glory for the good works that we display before others. To continue Blessings Pastor Phil Sessa

title.rendered: I am the Greatest 5 by Phil Sessa, Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning,

58 Jesus said to them, “Most assuredly, I say to you, ﻿before Abraham was, ﻿I AM.” 59﻿ Then﻿﻿they took up stones to throw at Him; but Jesus hid Himself and went out of the temple,﻿going ﻿through the midst of them, and so passed by (John 8:58 – 59).

In the book of Exodus Moses had an encounter with God, whereby he was called to go back to Egypt challenge the Pharaoh and command him to let the Hebrews go.  When Moses asked God “Who shall I say sent me?”  ﻿14﻿ …God said to Moses, “I AM WHO I AM.” And He said,“Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, ﻿﻿‘I AM has sent me to you (3:14).’  

In the New Testament Jesus is being challenged by the Jews as to His identity.  In the book of John, they are accusing him of being lesser then Abraham.  Jesus responds as says “I say to you, ﻿before Abraham was, ﻿I AM.”  This is an extremely significant response to their inquiry concerning His identity.  Notice how they responded to His statement, “Then ﻿﻿they took up stones to throw at Him…”  What in His response could have warranted such a reaction from the Jews?  To answer this question, one must look back to Levitical law.  Moses wrote, “﻿15﻿“Then you shall speak to the children of Israel, saying: ‘Whoever curses his God ﻿﻿shall ﻿﻿bear his sin. ﻿16﻿ And whoever ﻿﻿blasphemes the name of the Lord shall surely be put to death. All the congregation shall certainly stone him, the stranger as well as him who is born in the land. When he blasphemes the name of the Lord, he shall be put to death (Lev. 24:15-16).”  Now in looking back to the account back in the book of John, the Jews were looking to stone Jesus for blaspheming God’s name.  How did Jesus do this you ask?  When Christ said,“Before Abraham was I AM, He was referring to Himself being the SAME I AM that Moses spoke to at the burning bush from the book of Exodus.  Make no mistake about it, the focus was not merly that Jesus pre-existed Abraham as the Jehovah’s Witnesses would hold, but rather that Jesus was saying that HE HIMSELF was the I AM that Moses spoke to.  To avoid the obvious implication regarding the deity of Christ, Watchtower translators changed Jesus’words in the New World Translation to read: “Before Abraham came into existence, I have been (JW answered Verse by Verse).”

Matthew Henry wrote, “Our Saviour gives an effectual answer to this cavil, by a solemn assertion of his own seniority even to Abraham himself (v. 58): “Verily, verily, I say unto you; I do not only say it in private to my own disciples, who will be sure to say as I say, but to you my enemies and persecutors; I say it to your faces, take it how you will: Before Abraham was, I am;’’prin Abraam genesthai, egoµ eimi, Before Abraham was made or born, I am. The change of the word is observable, and bespeaks Abraham a creature, and himself the Creator; well therefore might he make himself greater than Abraham. Before Abraham he was, First, As God. I am, is the name of God (Ex. 3:14); it denotes his self-existence; he does not say, I was, but I am, for he is the first and the last, immutably the same (Rev. 1:8); thus he was not only before Abraham, but beforeall worlds, ch. 1:1; Prov. 8:23. Secondly, As Mediator. He was the appointed Messiah, long before Abraham; the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world (Rev. 13:8), the channel of conveyance of light, life, and love from God to man. This supposes his divine nature, that he is the same in himself from eternity (Heb. 13:8), and that he is the same to man ever since the fall; he was made of God wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption, to Adam, and Abel, and Enoch, and Noah, and Shem, and all the patriarchs that lived and died by faith in him before Abraham was born. Abraham was the root of the Jewish nation, the rock out of which they were hewn. If Christ was before Abraham, his doctrine and religion were no novelty, but were, in the substance of them, prior to Judaism, and ought to take place of it.”  They were deeply offended by the words of the Christ, the Great I AM, the One greater than Abraham, and greater than his hearers.

In John 14, Jesus is speaking to Philip, “Philip said to Him, “Lord, show us the Father, and it is sufficient for us.” ﻿9﻿ Jesus said to him, “Have I been with you so long, and yet you have not known Me, Philip? ﻿﻿He who has seen Me has seen the Father; so how can you say, ‘Show us the Father’? ﻿10﻿ Do you not believe that ﻿﻿I am in the Father, and the Father in Me?”  Jesus was“putting the nail in the coffin” as to who He was.  Since Philip saw Jesus, He saw God the Father (God in the flesh), because they are One (John 17).Every attempt to illustrate the trinity seems to pale in comparison to seeing it in the Scriptures, and believing this cardinal Christian doctrine by faith.  The trinity is true regardless of those that may deny it, and is what God, not Bible translators established.  Thank the Lord Jesus that He is the Great IAM, and that we can know Him, and do know Him if we are His children. 

Can you say with my, “I am a child of the I AM?!”  If so then rejoice and thank God for His salvation, and His greatness.  I you are not a born again Christian then today is the day to repent of your sins and put your trust in Christ alone for your salvation.  This great God, will be our Great Judge on the Great Judgment Day.  Make sure your life displays the fact that GOD IS GREAT!        

 Until the nets are filled…. 
Blessings, 
Phil the Evangelist <><

title.rendered: I AM THE GREATEST – “Greater than Solomon”, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“The queen of the south shall rise up in the judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: for she came from the uttermost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and, behold, a greater than Solomon is here.” (Matt. 12:42)

Previously we looked at Jesus prior statements of being greater then the temple and being greater then Jonah, and just how that was so.  Now He proclaims that He was also greater then Solomon.  Here is the account Jesus referred to from 1 King 1:1-10, when the queen of Sheba journeyed to see and meet Solomon to see if the claims she heard about his wisdom were true. 

“Arriving at Jerusalem with a very great caravan—with camels carrying spices, large quantities of gold, and precious stones—she came to Solomon and talked with him about all that she had on her mind. Solomon answered all her questions; nothing was too hard for the king to explain to her. When the queen of Sheba saw all the wisdom of Solomon and the palace he had built, the food on his table, the seating of his officials, the attending servants in their robes, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings he made at the temple of the LORD, she was overwhelmed. She said to the king, “The report I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom is true. But I did not believe these things until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half was told me; in wisdom and wealth you have far exceeded the report I heard. How happy your men must be! How happy your officials, who continually stand before you and hear your wisdom!  Praise be to the LORD your God, who has delighted in you and placed you on the throne of Israel. Because of the LORD’S eternal love for Israel, he has made you king, to maintain justice and righteousness.” And she gave the king 120 talents of gold, large quantities of spices, and precious stones. Never again were so many spices brought in as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.

Jesus mentioned that the Queen traveled to hear the wisdom of Solomon.  Jesus made the journey from heaven to earth to bring us His wisdom.  The Queen asked Solomon many questions, and although the content of those questions is unknown, I can imagine that they were important questions about the essence of life.  In John 1:1-4 the author explains that the Word, which translates to logos where we our word logic from, was always around from the beginning.  Proverbs 3:19 reads, “The Lord by wisdom has founded the Earth….” When Jesus came to Earth John 1:14 says that He was the Word (divine logic, wisdom) that, “…was made flesh and dwelt among us.”  Jesus the flawless divine wisdom of God came to show us the answer to the very essence of life, and even if He never spoke, which would not have been the case, because He was the very answer we needed.  If we needed money God would have sent a banker; if we needed entertainment God would have sent an entertainer; but we needed redemption so God sent a Savior.  Jesus said, “I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.”

The Queen was awed by all that Solomon built yet Jesus made Heaven and Earth.  She was taken back as she said, “Because of the LORD’S eternal love for Israel, he has made you king, to maintain justice and righteousness.”  Jesus is the King of King’s, the divine agape, the eternal love of God.  Paul said, “It is because of him that you are in Christ Jesus, who has become for us wisdom from God—that is, our righteousness, holiness and redemption.”

Application:  Jesus is the Messiah, who will introduce the promised eschatological age. Therefore the queen of Sheba will rise at the Judgment to condemning the unbelieving generation of Jesus’ time.  Share the One greater then Solomon daily with this generation. Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: I AM THE GREATEST “Greater Than Jonah”, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Mt 12:38 Then some of the Pharisees and teachers of the law said to him, “Teacher, we want to see a miraculous sign from you.” Mt 12:39 He answered, “A wicked and adulterous generation asks for a miraculous sign! But none will be given it except the sign of the prophet Jonah. Mt 12:40 For as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of a huge fish, so the Son of Man will be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth. Mt 12:41 The men of Nineveh will stand up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it; for they repented at the preaching of Jonah, and now one greater than Jonah is here.

Previously we looked into Jesus prior statement of being greater then the temple, and to do that we examined some of the elements that brought greatness to the temple.  Furthermore the temple with all its glory and splendor that contained the very presence of God was destroyed, as compared to the temple of Christ’s body which was destroyed and then miraculously raised from the grave.  First Jesus claimed that He was greater then the temple, and secondly He proclaimed that He was greater then Jonah. 

As we looked at the greatness of temple to see how Jesus surpassed its greatness so to must we look at the greatness of Jonah to make sense of Jesus’ greatness as compared to him.  First of all Jonah was a prophet called by God to go and preach repentance to the people of Nineveh.  However this prophet decided to run away from his calling and his mission and boarded a ship going in the opposite direction of where he was called to do.  If we stopped the story right here then Jonah isn’t such a hard act for Jesus to surpass.  Eventually Jonah was thrown overboard by the people on board, swallowed up by a big fish, perhaps a whale, and was inside that fish for three days and three nights.  He prayed while inside (see Jonah 2) and was eventually vomited up on shore.  He then preached repentance to the people of Nineveh and the whole city turned from their sin.  However he became angry that they repented and God had compassion on them and turned away His wrath. 

Jesus preached repentance toward God and faith in Him to the whole world not just one city like Jonah did with Nineveh.  While Jonah responded to the people’s repentance in anger, Jesus taught that all heaven rejoices over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent (Lk 15).  How much rejoicing went on in heaven over the whole city of Nineveh repenting?  Jesus further trained His disciples to preach repentance, and put His mission in their hands to carry the message to the world in His name.  Jesus wasn’t swallowed by a whale having to and vomited out, but greater then that He was swallowed up by death and death had to spit Him back out as God called His Son back from death unto life through resurrection.  Jesus was not only a prophet like Jonah but His was the very message itself (John 1:1,14).  When God wanted to reach Nineveh He sent Jonah.  However when God wanted to reach the world, He sent His Son Jesus.  Jonah ran from the will of God, I imagine, saying in his heart, “not thy will but my will be done.” Jesus prayed in the Garden, “not my will but Thy will be done.”  God gave Jonah a second chance, to fulfill the God call of God upon his life.  Jesus gave you and me a second chance to get right with Him before God’s wrath consumed our lives on Judgment Day, and thus fulfill God’s call upon our lives.

Application:  Who is your life reflecting more, the life of Jonah, or the Great One, Jesus?  When God calls you to do something for Him do you obey.  When is the last time you shared your faith, and showed another their need for repentance?     Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: I AM THE GREATEST “greater than the Temple”, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

For the next week or so, Pastor Phil, the evangelist will be sharing devotions with us. We’ve been blessed by his ministry and I appreciate him. Meanwhile keep me in your prayers for grace, strength, understanding, revelation of God’s word as I prepare and I teach on the book of Romans for 5 weeks at my church. Big book but exciting. Be blessed as Pastor Phil shares…

 Mohammed Ali was the World’s former heavyweight boxing champion.  He was known for dancing around saying, “I am the greatest! I am the greatest!” However a tragic scene took place a few years back at the Olympics when Ali was chosen to light the torch. He climbed up the stairs and with a palsied, Parkinson’s shake in his hand he could barely light that torch from the shaking in his body. Later in an interview he said, “God gave me that so I could remember that I’m not the greatest, but He is.” That’s pretty good advice, and a pretty good attitude.

Ali’s self proclaimed greatness was connected to his accomplishment in the ring.  As great and commendable of an accomplishment that was for Ali, it was only for a season, and therefore temporal.  Ecclesiastes 3 reminds us that, “There is a time for everything, and a season for every activity under heaven.”  Well if Ali isn’t the greatest, then perhaps the one remembered as Alexander the Great filled that title, which preceded Ali, however last I knew he was dead too.  Well then who is the greatest then? 

Jesus’ disciples surely grappled with this issue in their lives, and as they were arguing among themselves about which one of them was the greatest, Jesus drops a monkey wrench in the gears of their thinking as He said “The greatest among you will be your servant.”  I can picture the confused look on each of their faces as they struggled to understand Jesus’ words of servanthood. 

If we follow in the thinking of Christ, then to discover who the greatest one of all was we must look at the greatest servant in history.  The Apostle Paul writes, “Your attitude should be the same as that of Christ Jesus: Who, being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped, but made himself nothing, taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness.  And being found in appearance as a man, he humbled himself and became obedient to death—even death on a cross!  Therefore God exalted him to the highest place and gave him the name that is above every name, that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth, Phil 2:11 and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father (Phil 2:2-11).”

Paul points out that Jesus was God in the flesh, and took upon Himself the form of a servant, and that servanthood was connected to death as He died the death on the cross.  He faced capital punishment on that shameful cross, because He was a servant, but who did He serve?  Mark reminds us,…whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant, and whoever wants to be first must be slave of all. “For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many (10:43-45).”

There were other servants that lived both before and after Jesus.  However, only Jesus became a servant to all humanity giving His very life that all might receive salvation through Him.  No other person in history has ever come and served all of humanity past, present, and future, by their one life.  This is the greatness of Christ, and what makes Him unique above all others that have ever been proclaimed as great.  Unlike others, His greatness has no end because He is eternal. 

Application:  You serve a great God, thank Him today for His greatness and meditate on His greatness manifested in your life past and present, as you live to shine His greatness in the future.  Who are you serving to show your service to the Lord? Blessings Pastor Phil,fishdove1122@gmail.com

title.rendered: Moved By Feelings And Not By Situations

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Mark 9:14-29,”…But if You can do anything, have compassion on us and help us”

I would like to continue to encourage some folks who are still battling with life (family, careers, their walk with the Lord, and ministry). I believe it’s a message for me too. I am yet to meet people who have it all together, no struggle in their lives. I would present to us that where there is a will, there is away; where there is a problem, there is a solution; where there is hope, there is life; and where they is faith there is trust. Often times people don’t excel because of what they have believed,  so they stop fighting to move from point A to point B left feeling condemned in point A. All they now do is nurse all the failures and defeats they encountered previously. The bible says, “whose report will you believe”? As long as I have breath in me, I’m going to keep pumping life in me, encouraging myself that regardless of what I have gone through as long as it did not kill me, it gave me an opportunity to understand that greater things have been deposited in my spirit that will not be terminated prematurely. You and I did not come this far to call it quits, we still have to look to God as He shows us ways to survive in our desert experience in search for that water brook.

A loving father in my text has a child who has a deaf and dumb spirit. We are not told of his age but we are told of his condition. Many diseases that Jesus healed, He did not get into details trying to figure out when it started, what the symptoms were.  On this particular incident He gets information about who this child was and what he had. I do believe with all my heart about being specific with the Lord, general prayers have never worked for me that well and so when I have an issue, the first thing is to identify what it is, the symptoms, what it’s doing to me and being able to bring it to the Lord.

Just before Jesus came to the scene vs. 14, “Then one of the crowd answered and said, “Teacher, I brought You my son, who has a mute spirit… So I spoke to Your disciple, that they should cast it out, but they could not”. We see a caring father in need of help for his son. He brings his son to Jesus only to find His disciples instead. I can imagine the father thinking that since these people had been with Jesus, and had seen what Jesus regularly did, they too could perform miracles but they were unable. Was it because they were never equipped to do the job or was it a job just for the Master? Jesus tells us in John 14:12, “verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth in me, the works that I do shall he do also; and greater works than this shall he do”, with that verse, it’s very clear that Jesus would have loved to see His disciples do what He had been doing, the things He had been teaching them, listen to what He says in Mark 9:19, “He answered him and said, “O faithless generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I bare with you?” this implies He needed not to be there for the healing to take place for He had already given them power to heal, let’s see it in Mark 16:17&18, “And these signs shall follow them that believe; In my name they will cast out demons; they will speak with new tongues; they will take up serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it will by no means hurt them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover”. What a word from the Lord, He says, these signs shall follow you only if you believe (faith) and not just faith, but faith in the Author of it, Hebrews 12:2,”…looking unto Jesus the Author and the finisher (perfecter) of our faith”. Faith is the key that unlocks doors to victory.

Friends, we got to have faith that He who is in control is bigger than the situation and the circumstances around you and me. The reason why many cannot trust God with their situation is because they have reduced God to a level of “people breaking promises” and are in no position to help. I guarantee you that before you begin to even look to Him for anything, take Him out of the box you placed Him in, begin to praise Him, magnify His name, talk about His names, His nature and you will see how your faith will be elevated to a greater level. The thing that was a challenge will appear too small in your eyes for you are seeing it the same way the Lord sees it. Understand that whatever is impossible with man is possible with God; whatever gets out of man’s control does not get out of the Lord’s control. Have faith in God and the signs of victory, rain, joy, peace shall follow you for what intimidates you does not move Him. All the disciples needed in this case was faith and the name and the job would have been done. We too need the faith and the name to help us through it. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Forever the Victim? I don’t think so

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 4:1-13, “…Then Jesus being filled with the Holy Ghost, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, being tempted for forty days by the devil.

Jesus having been baptized by John part of His preparation for His ministry, full of the Holy Ghost was led into the wilderness by the Spirit. Thank God because constantly He leads us and I know that when He leads us, though we may go through the wilderness experience, He is preparing us for something awesome. That’s why I can stand with Job on this verse. Job 23:10, “He knows the way that I take, after He has tried me, I shall come forth as gold”

In the wilderness, the devil met Jesus and tempted Him 40days while He fasted. In His weak time in the flesh having fasted 40days and 40nights, the devil thought he could take advantage of Jesus’ weakness in the flesh. One thing the devil knew was that before Jesus came on earth He had power over the devil in heaven, because he was cast out of heaven. Now Jesus is on earth, in human form (flesh, body), flesh that gets tired, weary and tempted. The devil thought he now had Jesus this time and so he tries something on Him. Yes Jesus was tired and weak after fasting and so He was vulnerable to any attacks. Amazing thing, He had a different weapon to fight back. He had the word and every time the devil tried tempting Him, He responded “IT IS WRITTEN”. The word has power if used correctly ‘because the devil also quoted scriptures in this passage but not in its proper use. After the enemy tried Him three times and failed, he left Jesus for a season and the angels came and ministered to Him (Matt 4:11). We as believers will be tried persistently and when we have resisted with the word, the devil will leave us for a season, meaning he is bound to come back, and when he leaves, the angels will strengthen us. Arm yourself with the word at all times!!!

Aren’t we glad that we can be weak in the flesh and we can be tempted but we can retaliate using the word of God? When discouragements come, we need to have a word to fight it back and we can tell the devil, IT IS WRITTEN. Be it fear, anxiety, failure, you name it, everything has a word to address it. Let’s face all our obstacles today and forever with the word that is written. If the enemy tempts you with fear, say to him, it’s written, “For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of Power and of love and of sound mind, 2Tim 1:7”, if he says you can’t be blessed, say to him, it is written, “But my God shall supply all my need according to His riches in glory by Christ Jesus, Phil 4:19“. Refuse to be the devils little toy he plays with when you are vulnerable. How many times have we yielded to him our strength in the past? Well the past is gone; this is a new day we refuse to go down when we have God’s word. Forever the victim? I don’t think so. Speak the word!!! Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 1:46, “And Nathanael said to him, “Can anything good come out of Nazareth?”

I am constantly battling whether there are good things that can come out of me and my surrounding. The bible already says, “There is nothing good in us (that is in ourselves)”, I believe you find yourself in this dilemma sometimes. When you have waited for so long, labored hard, did all you could but still wonder whether any good can come out of you? You might have a habit you have been trying to get rid of for years, it has left you crippled in some way and you are constantly thinking, “Can any good thing come out of me even in this situation?” At times you want to rip off what is standing on the way of your victory because you can feel it, sense it, see it but you can’t seam to find away to gain it.

I have not studied the history of Nazareth but by listening to what Nathanael had to say, there was something about it that couldn’t allow him to see anything good come out of it. Maybe the sins in that city were great and if we look at the records, we see Jesus having a hard time in Nazareth where He grew, many were offended and wanted to cast Him out, the bible says that twice He was expelled from the city, there was unbelief and perhaps they were rude people. From the book of Genesis to the book of Malachi, there are prophesies of birth of Jesus mentioned and how He would become the King, Messiah, Emanuel, Lord, born of a virgin in Bethlehem. If a baby like that would be born today, they would find the best city, hospital, in other words, the best place to have him. It will be all over news. Jesus wasn’t like that, yet, He had all the titles. So when Phillip approached Nathanael to give him the good news of having met Christ, the one they had all been waiting for, it did not make sense to him. To make it worse, Phillip referred to Him as Jesus of Nazareth. We do want good things to come out of good places and we can put our focus on that good place and fail to understand that God tends to do things differently why? 1Corinthians 1:27, “God has chosen the foolish things of the world to put to shame the wise, and God has chosen the weak things of the world to put to shame the things which are might“. I’m always amazed because we tend to program ourselves as to how God will move and if He does not move as expected and anticipated, we get frustrated. Don’t focus on how He moves, focus on this thought, HE MOVES.

John 1:46, “… Can anything good come out of Nazareth?”. Can anything good come out of your  position at work; in your husband who you think is not amounting to anything, a child that is just out of place, giving you a hard time and you sit and wonder, can anything good come out of him/her?. How about you have been sick for many years or trying to stop a habit, nothing is happening. You are just like Nathanael who could not see beyond the sins in Nazareth. People who cannot see beyond their weakness and some people  are always left wondering whether there is anything good left reserved for such people in spite of who they are. We praise God for the great things He is doing even in the midst of all the things we do not see Him use to bring that which is good. Jesus Christ came out of Nazareth, the Christ in each of us helps us and others see that good things can come out of us (boldness, courage, strength, joy, peace, victories etc). It’s not a matter of how you feel, it’s a matter of who comes out of the city that no one ever thought something good could come out of.

Christ came out of Nazareth in spite of Nathanael’s thought. Jesus revealed Himself at that point, John 1:49, “Then Nathanael declared, Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the King of Israel. vs. 50, ” Jesus said, …. You shall see greater things than that”. Praise God because we will see Him do things and greater things than this shall we see. Jesus makes disappointments into appointments, junks into assets, mess into order, and doubt into faith. Next time you see something or someone or in yourself that nothing good could come out of you, may you be reminded that it can because of Him. Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 10:38-42, “40 But Martha was DISTRACTED with MUCH serving, and she approached Him and said, “Lord, do You not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Therefore tell her to help me.”  41And Jesus answered and said to her, “Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled about many things. 42 But one thing is needed, and Mary has chosen that good part, which will not be taken away from her.”

If each of us was to take time to closely look at our lives, we will find that we have too many distractions. And distractions bring about detachment, moving your attention away from what you should be concentrating on, very important things. Sometimes we get distracted by even good things but not necessary at a given time.

We see this example in Luke 10:38 when Jesus entered into a village and Martha welcomed Him into her house. It was Martha’s idea to welcome the Son of God; her sister did not have part in it. If you welcome someone or a distinguished guest, presentation is very important right? And I can see Martha working hard to give a good presentation; cooking, cleaning, setting things up because she had a guest in her house. Then here comes Mary, Martha’s sister who instead of helping her, sat at Jesus feet to hear His words. While one was busy prepping the natural food, the other was busy sitting to feed on spiritual food.

Isn’t it amazing that we too can be busy prepping things for the Lord but forget the most important thing, sit at His feet and feed on His word, be in prayer? How easy it is to be distracted doing everything else for the Lord but have no time for Him. Yes, Jesus was in Martha’s house but I believe it’s not so much about what Martha could give to the Lord but rather what the Lord could give to her and her household if she wasn’t distracted. While distracted and waiting for her sister to come and help, I can imagine frustrations beginning to creep in and that is when she turned to the Lord to ask her sister to come and help. Instead of Jesus asking Mary to go and help her sister, He said “Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled about many things.” Any time in the bible the Lord calls a person twice; I believe it was to get that person’s undivided attention. See the Lord noticed that she was worried and troubled by many things trying to please the Lord. What she would have learnt was that pleasing the Lord meant sitting at His feet to hear Him teach why,John 4:34, “Jesus said to them, “My food is to do the will of Him who sent Me, and to finish His work” and for Mary Romans 10:17, “So then faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God” and Mary chose the best thing, Jesus continues to say, “42 But one thing is needed, and Mary has chosen that good part, which will not be taken away from her.”

If you were to take a moment right now and scan your life, would you find anything distracting you from being in His presence and listening to His voice? Do you have too many things going on that has shifted your focus from what is important that even reading His word and praying are not appearing to be your priority? Martha was distracted that she missed the food for her soul, Mary chose the best. Are you going to be a Mary or a Martha? Don’t let distractions shift your focus. Blessings Ev
